name: Magnesium
summary: Magnesium is an essential mineral involved in numerous biochemical processes, including neurotransmission and stress regulation. Various forms of magnesium are used as supplements for anxiety, depression, sleep, and overall mental health.
description: Magnesium is a vital mineral that plays roles in neuromuscular function, neurotransmitter regulation, and energy metabolism. Deficiency has been associated with depression, anxiety, migraines, and insomnia. Supplementation is common in integrative psychiatry, though clinical evidence is variable depending on formulation and condition. Different forms of magnesium vary in absorption, tolerability, and clinical effects—making the choice of formulation important for therapeutic use in mental health.

metadata.natural_source: Leafy greens, nuts, seeds, whole grains, legumes
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for psychiatric indications)

monitoring_required: Serum magnesium levels (in high-dose supplementation or renal impairment)

items.name: Magnesium Citrate
items.notes: Highly bioavailable, often used for relaxation and mild constipation. May support anxiety relief.

items.name: Magnesium Glycinate
items.notes: Chelated with glycine, well absorbed, calming effects, commonly used for sleep and anxiety.

items.name: Magnesium Oxide
items.notes: High elemental magnesium content but poor absorption; mainly used for constipation and migraines.

items.name: Magnesium L-Threonate
items.notes: Crosses the blood–brain barrier; studied for cognitive enhancement, depression, and anxiety.

items.name: Magnesium Malate
items.notes: Bound to malic acid; supports energy metabolism and may benefit fatigue syndromes.

items.name: Magnesium Taurate
items.notes: Bound to taurine; potential benefits for cardiovascular health and calming effects.

items.name: Magnesium Sulfate
items.notes: Primarily used intravenously in hospitals (eclampsia, arrhythmias). Oral use uncommon.

items.name: Magnesium Chloride
items.notes: Moderate absorption, sometimes used topically or in liquid supplements.

sections.text: Magnesium modulates NMDA receptors, enhancing GABAergic signaling and reducing excitotoxicity. It plays a role in regulating the HPA axis, neurotransmitter release, and circadian rhythm. In mental health, magnesium may reduce stress reactivity and improve sleep quality.

adult.range: 150–600 mg elemental magnesium daily depending on condition and form

sections.pediatric: 100–250 mg daily, age-dependent (for deficiency; psychiatric uses not well established)

sections.text: Sleep and relaxation effects may appear within days; mood and migraine benefits may take 4–8 weeks.

other: Excessive doses may cause diarrhea or electrolyte imbalance
Caution in renal impairment due to accumulation risk

items: Serum magnesium levels in long-term or high-dose use
Renal function if supplementation is chronic and high dose

sections.pregnancy: Generally safe at recommended doses; high doses should be supervised
sections.pediatrics: Safe at age-appropriate doses; consult for higher therapeutic use
sections.geriatrics: Safe, but monitor renal function and bowel tolerance

sections.text: No tapering required; discontinuation is safe though deficiency symptoms may return if intake is inadequate.

items: Formulation matters: glycinate and threonate are best tolerated for psychiatric uses.
Magnesium deficiency is common due to modern diets and may contribute to treatment-resistant depression or anxiety.
Topical magnesium has limited evidence for systemic absorption.

items.label: Boyle NB et al. The effects of magnesium supplementation on subjective anxiety and stress—systematic review. Nutrients. 2017.
Eby GA, Eby KL. Rapid recovery from major depression using magnesium treatment. Med Hypotheses. 2006.
